:For other uses, see [[Concordance]].

'Concordance' as used in genetics usually means the presence of the same trait
in both members of a pair of twins. However, the strict definition is the
probability that a pair of individuals will both have a certain characteristic,
given that one of the pair has the characteristic. For example, twins are
concordant when both have or both lack a given trait. R. Lewontin, Human
Diversity. (Scientific American Press, 1982) Ideally, concordance includes
that of identical twins.
